review.title: Recent advances on inconsistency indices for pairwise comparisons - a commentary
review.abstract: This paper recalls the definition of consistency for pairwise comparison matrices and briefly presents the concept of inconsistency index in connection to other aspects of the theory of pairwise comparisons. By commenting on a recent contribution by Koczkodaj and Szwarc, it will be shown that the discussion on inconsistency indices is far from being over, and the ground is still fertile for debates.

metadata.title: Recent advances on inconsistency indices for pairwise comparisons — a commentary∗

sections.text: This paper recalls the definition of consistency for pairwise comparison matrices and briefly introduces the concept of the inconsistency index in conjunction with other aspects of the theory of pairwise comparisons.By commenting on a recent paper by Koczkodaj and Szwarc, it is shown that the discussion of inconsistency indices is far from over and the ground for debate is still fertile.Keywords: pairwise comparisons, estimated preference relationships, consistency, inconsistency index, analytical hierarchy process

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In modern decision-making methods, such as the Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP), the use of pairwise comparisons between the various alternatives has been strongly advocated, and the most widespread representation of estimated preferences is based on the pairwise comparison used by Saaty in the AHP. Faced with a finite, not empty set of actions, it was called: Brunelli M., Recent avances on inconsistency indices for pairwise comparisons - a computerwise comparisons, 144 (3-4), 321-332, 2016. doi: 10.333 / FI-138.280v: a pairwise comparisons - a computerwise comparisons, Fundamenta Informaticae, 144 (3-4).

sections.heading: 2 The central role of inconsistency indices
sections.text: In fact, it is that we are able to assert ourselves, that we are able, that we are able to achieve our goals, and that we are able to achieve our goals.

sections.heading: 3 (Re)opening the debate on inconsistency indices
sections.text: Despite the diversity of indices proposed in the literature, there have been no axiomatic studies until recently. Two of the most recent proposals for axiomatization came from Brunelli and Fedrizzi [7] 1 and from Koczkodaj and Szwarc [24]. In addition to presenting separate axiomatic systems, the two proposals differ in their conclusions, with Koczkodaj and Szwarc being more drastic. To cut a long story short, the first two axioms are simple regularity conditions, while the third seems to be rather restrictive. These three axioms have the form of appropriate properties and serve the implicit definition of inconsistency indices. In agreement with this, the authors claimed that their axiomatic system "allows us to define inconsistencies when they then provide a function."

sections.heading: 3.1 The triad and the matrix
sections.text: The interpretation of the third axiom of Koczkodaj and Szwarelli is problematic because of its ambiguous definition and the soundness of the stated motivation. According to them [24]: "It is a reasonable expectation that the degradation of a triad used in the definition of consistency cannot make the whole matrix more consistent." The following example calls their expectation into question. Consider the matrix 1 2 2 4 4 4 4 4 1 / 4 1 1 1 1 / 3 1 / 4 1 / 2 1. The entry a15 appears in the triads (a12, a25, a15), a35, a15) and (a15, a15). Let us write it down in more detail.

sections.heading: 3.2 The role of an axiomatic system
sections.text: As Koczkodaj and Szwarc correctly claim [24], in this context an axiomatic system is used to define a series of functions, which in principle are all suitable to represent a certain property of a mathematical object. Many other axiomatic systems work in a similar manner, such as the axiomatic definition of distance in metric spaces or the norm in linear spaces. It should follow that if a function that I perform their three axioms, then this same function should be respected as an inconsistency index (at least by the authors who proposed the axioms in linear spaces). Considering the ambiguous formulation (especially regarding the third axiom), by considering a 3 × 3 pairwise comparison matrixA3 × 3 = 1 aiczom aik1 / aiczom 1 ajom 1 / aik 1, the axiomatic system of Koczkodadadaj and the 1 is waromatic.

sections.heading: 3.3 One rotten apple does not necessarily spoil the barrel
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to survive by not following the rules they have imposed on themselves. In fact, it is that they are not able to follow the rules, and that they are able to follow the rules. In fact, it is that they are not following the rules. In fact, they are not following the rules.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text: Let us forget for a moment the object and instead consider the following two norms of the vector x = (x1,.., xn). Ideally, as also proposed by Horn and Johnson [18], a norm should capture the "size" of a vector. N1 and N2 capture two views of the "size" of x, namely N1 represents the component-based contributions, whereas N2 only takes into account the largest. Consequently, they can give very different answers to the question regarding the "consistency" of the vector x. Nevertheless, they are both norms, since they respect the axiomatic conditions for norms. Considering the vector x = (3, 0, 0, 0).

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The author is grateful to the anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments.

By commenting on a recent contribution by Koczkodaj and Szwarc, it will be shown that the discussion on inconsistency indices is far from being over, and the ground is still fertile for debates.
